docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, April 9--The Carter Administration, after an interagency dispute, has decided to grant a significant trade concession to Pakistan as part of its efforts to help that country economically.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 9--The Carter Administration, after an interagency dispute, has decided to grant a significant trade concession to Pakistan as part of its efforts to help that country economically.
docs.abstract: Carter Administration to grant significant trade concession to Pakistan as part of its efforts to help country; concession could have effect of exempting Pakistan from countervailing duties on its Govt-subsidized textile and apparel shipments to US; decision has angered people in domestic textile industry, and is causing complications in US trade relationships with other developing nations (M)

headline.main: U.S. to Give Pakistan Trade Concession on Textiles; Brazil and Uruguay Cited

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: THIS is V.S. Naipaul's 16th book, and I should probably say, straight off, that it has become impossible to write about a new Naipaul  book without the kind of anxious homage that kills enthusiasm. Naipaul is a writer of genius, but this,
docs.lead_paragraph: THIS is V.S. Naipaul's 16th book, and I should probably say, straight off, that it has become impossible to write about a new Naipaul book without the kind of anxious homage that kills enthusiasm. Naipaul is a writer of genius, but this,
docs.abstract: The Return of Eva Peron reviewed by Jane Kramer

docs.snippet: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 14 (AP)-- Guerrillas belonging to the same group that is holding 18 diplomats hostage in the Dominican Republic's Embassy here charged into the Uruguayan Embassy today but fled when they could not find the Acting Ambassador,...
docs.lead_paragraph: BOGOTA, Colombia, April 14 (AP)-- Guerrillas belonging to the same group that is holding 18 diplomats hostage in the Dominican Republic's Embassy here charged into the Uruguayan Embassy today but fled when they could not find the Acting Ambassador, police sources reported.
docs.abstract: guerrillas belonging to same group that is holding 18 diplomats raid Uruguayan Embassy but flee when they cannot find Acting Ambassador Raul Lira; are believed to be acting in reprisal for escape of Uruguay's Ambassador Fernando Gomez from occupied Dominican Republic Embassy on March 17; representatives of guerrillas and Government hold 2 negotiating sessions on release of US Ambassador Diego C Asencio and other hostages (M)

headline.main: Colombian Guerrillas Said to Fail in Attack On a Second Embassy

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, April 16--Despite new signs of support from some American allies for boycotting the Moscow Olympics, Carter Administration aides said today that they were still uncertain of how much backing the boycott would command.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 16--Despite new signs of support from some American allies for boycotting the Moscow Olympics, Carter Administration aides said today that they were still uncertain of how much backing the boycott would command.
docs.abstract: Carter Adm aides, despite new signs of support from some American allies for boycotting Moscow Olympics, say they are still uncertain of how much backing boycott would command; tally of nations being kept by Adm suggests that about 34 nations will boycott Games, 10 to 14 appear leaning toward boycott and 15 to 20 are either undecided or leaning against boycott (M)

headline.main: EXTENT OF SUPPORT ON GAMES IS UNCLEAR; 34 Nations Will Probably Pass Up Olympics, Carter Tally Shows, but Many Are Undecided A Rules Change Is Contemplated Nation Certain Not to Go

byline.original: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: WHEN Dr. Mark Gerard substituted a fast horse for a slow one in New York rac  ing's most celebrated ringer case, he got a year in the stammer and the horse got life. Dr. Gerard has not yet served time, and the ringer, a horse named Cinzano, is racing...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Dr. Mark Gerard substituted a fast horse for a slow one in New York rac ing's most celebrated ringer case, he got a year in the stammer and the horse got life. Dr. Gerard has not yet served time, and the ringer, a horse named Cinzano, is racing again, but without purses and without visible betting.
docs.abstract: Article examines history of horse Cinzano, allegedly owned by Dr Mark Gerard, and controversy surrounding him; illus (M)

headline.main: Sports of The Times; Cinzano Goes Over the Jumps

docs.snippet: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 9 (AP)  An international team with representatives from the United States, Britain and Costa Rica plans to go to Havana next week to help the Cuban Government organize an orderly exodus of the Cuban refugees, an 18-nation...
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 9 (AP) An international team with representatives from the United States, Britain and Costa Rica plans to go to Havana next week to help the Cuban Government organize an orderly exodus of the Cuban refugees, an 18-nation conference announced here today.
docs.abstract: 18-nation conference says international team with representatives from US, GB and Costa Rica plans to go to Havana next week to help Cuban Government organize orderly exodus of Cuban refugees; Costa Rican official says Cuban Government has agreed in principle to allow team to enter Cuba; 18 countries also agree to take in some refugees and pledge total of $1 million to help with exodus; Costa Rica's Pres Rodrigo Carazo Odio organized meeting; member nations noted (M)

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, May 16--Argentina's banking authorities have contained a crisis produced by the bankruptcy of the country's two biggest private banks but at substantial cost to the Government's anti-inflation program.
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, May 16--Argentina's banking authorities have contained a crisis produced by the bankruptcy of the country's two biggest private banks but at substantial cost to the Government's anti-inflation program.
docs.abstract: Argentina's banking authorities have contained crisis produced by bankruptcy of nation's 2 biggest private banks but at substantial cost to Government's anti-inflation program; there is widespread speculation in banking circles that gradual, controlled devaluation of peso at monthly rate of about 2% will have to be replaced by major devaluation because of mounting inflation, which is making Argentine exports increasingly competitive; accumulation of foreign reserves, which reached $10 billion over past 3 years, has been reversed; outflow of dollars from central bank in past month averaged $30 million a day; other economic problems noted (M)

headline.main: Argentine Economy Hurt by Bank Crisis; Inflation Fueled By Reactions Other Economic Woes

byline.original: By JUAN de ONIS Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, May 17--The Presidents of Argentina and Brazil signed a series of agreements today to expand economic and political cooperation between their countries.
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, May 17--The Presidents of Argentina and Brazil signed a series of agreements today to expand economic and political cooperation between their countries.
docs.abstract: Among cooperation agreements signed by Argentina and Brazil on May 17 is one covering integration of electric-power systems along Parana River (S)

headline.main: Argentina and Brazil in New Ties; 'Vast Area of Common Interest'
